clues.text: A male goose you might take a look at
Garbology is the study of this, not of Greta Garbo movies
A small cave, perhaps a "blue" one
It's the slang term for a newcomer to India, even if his first name isn't Merv
Perhaps from the Latin for "throat", it's a noise made by brooks & babies
In an 1884 work, runaway slave Jim rafts down the Mississippi with this title character
The Associated Press named him the greatest male athlete of the first half of the 20th century
In this 1939 book, the Joads run into Jim Casy, a preacher who becomes an activist
Name shared by a Minnesota Twins pitcher & a "Sale Of The Century" host
This Speaker of the House resigned in 1989 under charges of wrongdoing
Its capital was East Berlin
In 1902 Panama was still part of this country
Bangladesh was known as this until a 1971 civil war
When part of the Soviet Union, this country was abbreviated the B.S.S.R.
In 1954 French Indochina was divided into these 4 countries
clues.response: Cambodia, Laos, North Vietnam & South Vietnam

clues.text: Can we talk about this funny lady's books? -- they include "Enter Talking" & "From Mother To Daughter"
In "In the Arena", he takes readers behind the scenes of such movies as "Ben-Hur"
"Holiday in Your Heart", about a young country singer, was co-written by this teen country sensation
Good heavens!  This star of TV's "7th Heaven" wrote the erotic thriller "Eye Contact"
This zany duo reveals the "magical" secrets of "How To Play With Your Food" & "How To Play In Traffic"
A dream angel tells this New Testament man to "Take the young child and his mother, and flee into Egypt"
He said "little people" in his dreams inspired stories like "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde"
Chemist Friedrich Kekule described the benzene molecule after dreaming of this creature swallowing its tail
This director of "M*A*S*H" & "Nashville" based his 1977 film "Three Women" on one of his dreams
According to Plutarch, in the 300s B.C., Persian king Darius dreamed this conqueror would wait on him
Static positions combine with rapid movements in this event where you grasp 2 hanging parallel hoops
This gymnastics event is performed by both men & women on a mat without any other equipment
She's the legendary gymnast famous for using "The Young and the Restless" theme song in 1976
In this men's event, it's "routine" to work your way around a long leather-covered apparatus
A relative newcomer to the Olympics, this type of gymnastics uses ropes, clubs, balls, hoops & ribbons
She cleverly disguises herself as a lawyer & saves Antonio from Shylock's revenge
Laertes tells her, "For Hamlet and the trifling of his favor" are "not permanent, sweet, not lasting"
He's the storm-raising Duke of "The Tempest"
A setting in "As You Like It", it's also the name of an ancient wooded area near Shakespeare's home
"Pandosto: The Triumph of Time" was the source for this "Tale" of romance

Meaning "nourishing mother", these 2 Latin words are used when referring to your college
Some criminal investigations are done this way, meaning "after death"
You'll be on the money knowing "out of many, one" is the translation of this Latin phrase
Literally meaning "under the rose", it means to do something covertly or in secret
Music lovers know it's Latin for "work" & its plural form is a type of musical work
Parents & kids gather each year at the White House for this event held on the Monday after Easter
Hindi faithful make regular pilgrimages to & bathe in this 1,560-mile river of Northern India
In the 1820s thirsty explorers found an oasis here, Spanish for "the meadows"; 30 million now visit every year
Traditionally, crowds gather in New Orleans & party hearty before this first day of Lent
Bring your pet to the USA's National Cathedral on Oct. 4 for "The Blessing of the Animals" for this saint's feast day
This man worked with Robert Havell on some etchings so that his "Birds of America" could find a publisher
He created etchings of Paul Gachet, a doctor who in 1890 took him in & cared for him at Auvers
One of his most famous etchings is "Christ Healing the Sick", aka "The 100-Guilder Print", completed in the 1640s
This British artist known for his "Marriage a la Mode" engravings had a 1735 copyright act named for him
His "Ancient of Days" was the frontispiece to his 1794 poem "Europe, A Prophecy"
Scientists once believed that Pluto was an escaped satellite of this planet
Named after the planet, the highly radioactive element plutonium has this atomic symbol; does it smell bad?
In 1905 this man for whom an Arizona observatory is named started a search for Pluto
Discovered in 1978, this moon of Pluto bears the name of a Greek mythological ferryman on the River Styx
In 1930 he discovered Pluto; in 2006 some of his ashes were headed there aboard NASA's New Horizons mission
